repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body: `cythonize` by default creates just C file. Can we mention here that the user should run `cythonize` with `-b` option?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,6 +18,8 @@ one may want to read more about
 There are several ways to build Cython code:
 
  - Write a setuptools ``setup.py``. This is the normal and recommended way.
+ - Run the ``cythonize`` command-line utility. This is a good approach for

comment_data.body:
Ah. I didn't know that. I usually run `cythonize -i filename` when I use it. But really I've just found the first option that worked and kept using it...

We probably should recommend a command line that works, yes
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,6 +18,8 @@ one may want to read more about
 There are several ways to build Cython code:
 
  - Write a setuptools ``setup.py``. This is the normal and recommended way.
+ - Run the ``cythonize`` command-line utility. This is a good approach for

comment_data.body:
Yes `-i` also enables `-b` automatically:

```
  -b, --build           build extension modules using distutils
  -i, --inplace         build extension modules in place using distutils (implies -b)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,6 +18,8 @@ one may want to read more about
 There are several ways to build Cython code:
 
  - Write a setuptools ``setup.py``. This is the normal and recommended way.
+ - Run the ``cythonize`` command-line utility. This is a good approach for

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
   compiling a single Cython source file directly to an extension.
   A source file can be built "in place" (so that the extension module is generated next to the source file) with
  ``cythonize -i filename.pyx``.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,6 +18,8 @@ one may want to read more about
 There are several ways to build Cython code:
 
  - Write a setuptools ``setup.py``. This is the normal and recommended way.
+ - Run the ``cythonize`` command-line utility. This is a good approach for
+   compiling a single Cython source file directly to an extension.

comment_data.body:
I've recommended `-i` just because it's what I usually do. I think the main thing to do here is just give a usable command to get them going. People can look up all the available options in elsewhere if they want.

Thanks for the suggestion!
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,6 +18,8 @@ one may want to read more about
 There are several ways to build Cython code:
 
  - Write a setuptools ``setup.py``. This is the normal and recommended way.
+ - Run the ``cythonize`` command-line utility. This is a good approach for

@@ -18,6 +18,8 @@ one may want to read more about
 There are several ways to build Cython code:
 
  - Write a setuptools ``setup.py``. This is the normal and recommended way.
+ - Run the ``cythonize`` command-line utility. This is a good approach for

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
   A source file can be built "in place" (so that the extension module is created
   next to the source file, ready to be imported) with ``cythonize -i filename.pyx``.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,6 +18,10 @@ one may want to read more about
 There are several ways to build Cython code:
 
  - Write a setuptools ``setup.py``. This is the normal and recommended way.
+ - Run the ``cythonize`` command-line utility. This is a good approach for
+   compiling a single Cython source file directly to an extension.
+   A source file can be built "in place" (so that the extension module is generated next to the source file) with
+  ``cythonize -i filename.pyx``.

commit.message: Add a note about cythonize in the quickstart documentation

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Add a note about cythonize in the quickstart documentation
